a b s t r a c t
As a breakthrough to open up the industrial use of novel environmentally benign packaging material, we propose the first report on portable chitosan-ZnO nano-composite pouches that will serve as elite entrants in smart packaging. A facile, one pot procedure was adopted for the preparation of the C-ZnC films. In order to tune the property of C-ZnC films, four different composite films were prepared by varying the concentration of ZnO. The prepared films were found to be much superior when compared to bare chitosan and other conventional films. Two bacterial strains that commonly contaminate in packed meat were selected as target microbes to elucidate the antimicrobial activity of the prepared C-ZnO film. Detailed investigations revealed that the antimicrobial efficiency is linearly related to the amount of
ne pot synthesize nti microbial packaging systems
ZnO nano-particles in the composite. The C-2 films exhibited excellent antimicrobial activity and was fabricated into packaging pouches for raw meat. The prepared pouches showed significant action against the microbes in raw meat owing to its complete inhibition of microbial growth on the sixth day of storage at 4 ◦C. The C-2 pouches stand as a top-notch material when compared to polyethylene bag in extending the shelf life of raw meat.

. Introduction
Smart packaging refers to that form of intelligent packaging hich in any route extends the shelf life and improves the safety or ensory properties of food and allied products without compromisng its quality [1]. In the present era, there exists a huge demand or smart packaging materials and research on packaging materils is gaining momentum among the scientific community. Smart ackaging materials play a pivotal role in maintaining the qualty and freshness of food products especially perishable foods like eat, fruits, milk, juices, etc. Among the perishable goods, meat is ighly prone to decay and hence there is always a cry for an efficient ackaging material for meat. Unfortunately traditional methods of reserving meat from the effect of microbial contamination comrising of drying, freezing, refrigerating, and adding antimicrobial gents or salts are neither cost effective nor efficient. Vulnerable rowth of microbes on the meat surface stands as a major hurle in its packaging, this microbial growth unanimously affects he shelf-life of meat. The popular methods of using antibacterial prays or dips have limited benefits since the active substances re neutralized on contact or will diffuse rapidly into the bulk of

food, away from the surface [2]. Hence the foremost criterion for an ideal smart packaging system is that it must have antimicrobial efficacy. Therefore the notion of packaging films incorporated with antimicrobial agents is a novel focal theme in the development of new generation smart packaging materials. Apart from this, it must have portability, optimal water sorption capacity, high mechanical strength, physico-chemical stability, microbial safety, environmentally benign and cost effective [3]. Both synthetic and biopolymers have been exploited as packaging films. However, the idea of synthetic polymers with antimicrobial agent is totally obsolete in the present scenario of environmental issues.
Nowadays, there is a drastic shift from synthetic polymer to biopolymer to develop new generation packaging films. Chitosan, the second most abundant biopolymer is widely acclaimed as packaging films owing to its intriguing properties like availability from natural resources, biodegradability, ability to form excellent films and antimicrobial efficacy. Researchers have focused on chitosan as an alternative for petroleum derived polymer films [4]. However, the use of chitosan alone does not fulfill the criteria for an ideal packaging film. Chitosan is found to be permeable to water which may promote bacterial growth and also it is not much effective against common bacterial strains that cause food spoilage. Recently, the limited mechanical and antimicrobial property of chitosan films have changed the attention of researchers to modify naive chitosan films for better performance [5]. Hence it is always

The ability of Chitosan to accommoate new materials in its matrix can be correlated to the presence f large number of pendant groups like NH2 and OH [7]. The ybridization of various nano functional materials with chitosan ill improve the performance of Chitosan films by tuning its physcal and chemical properties. The enhancement of properties can be ttributed to the synergistic interaction between host matrix and unctional material. Researchers have synthesized various types of hitosan composites, with nanoparticles having at least one dimenion in nanoscale [8–17]. Nano ZnO particles are emerging as a opular additive in the class of chitosan based bionanocomposte films. According to U.S. Food and Drug Administration protocol 21CFR182.8991), ZnO is considered as a generally recognized safe GRAS) material [18]. The remarkable stability and antibacterial ctivity of ZnO have under lined its status as a suitable blend for hitosan matrix [19].
Herein, we present the first report on chitosn-ZnO based ortable pouches that have the capacity to extend the shelf life of aw meat by complete inhibition of bacterial growth. In this study, hitosan-ZnO nano composite film was synthesized by a simple ne pot procedure and was adequately characterized by using XRD, TIR, SEM, etc. The influence of noted factors such as water sorption apacity, water solubility, and thermal stability was investigated n detail. The antimicrobial test of the synthesized films revealed heir efficiency in controlling bacterial growth. We believe that the ouches developed can be conveniently employed as a packagng material for raw meat which creates significant advances in ackaging industry.
. Experimental
.1. Materials
Chitosan with 85% degree of deacetylation was purchased from igma Aldrich Co. Ltd (USA). Acetic acid, sodium hydroxide and zinc cetate dihydrate were obtained from Merck (Germany). Mineral alt broth and Nutrient agar were purchased from Himedia Chemcals (Mumbai, India). Two bacterial strains Escherichia coli (E-Coli,
TCC737) and Staphylococcus Aureus (S-Aureus, MTCC 1687) were ultured in the UniBiosys Biotech Research Lab, Cochin. Deionized
synthesis of C-ZnC films.
water was used to prepare all solutions. All the chemicals were analytical grade and used without further purification.
2.2. Preparation of films
Chitosan nano ZnO composite films were prepared by the solution casting technology. 2 g of chitosan flakes was dissolved in 100 mL of 2% (v/v) aqueous acetic acid using ultrasonication for 2 h at room temperature. Subsequently, 2 g of zinc acetate dihydrate was added into this solution and the reaction mixture was again sonicated for 1 h to form a homogeneous dispersion. To obtain even films, 25 mL of the viscous mixture was casted in to a circular glass dish and was dried at room temperature. Glass plates with dried thin films were immersed in 0.2 mol L−1 sodium hydroxide solution for wet phase separation (12 h). After coagulation, the solidified films were washed well with distilled water and kept in a constant temperature oven kept at 60 ± 0.2 ◦C for 4 h. The resulting nanocomposite films (C-2) were then washed with methanol and double distilled water for three times and was dried. The scheme of preparation of film was illustrated in Fig. 1. Three more nanocomposite films were prepared by adopting the same procedure with different quantity of zinc acetate (1.5, 1.0 and 0.5 g); named as C1.5, C-1 and C-0.5 respectively. A pure chitosan film was prepared without zinc acetate and named as C.
2.3. Characterization of films
FT-IR Spectra of the films were calibrated using an Attenuated Total Reflection (ATR) Technique (Model, Perkin Elmer Inc. USA). Films were cut into disc shape (5 mm × 5 mm) and placed gently on diamond ATR crystal. Prior to the analysis, the film was locked with the pressure arm to maintain an ample contact between sample and the crystal. The absorption was measured between 400 and 4000 cm −1. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were obtained in the scanning range of 20–75◦ by a X-ray diffractometer (Model: Rigaku Minifex 600 diffractometer) with Cu K radiation ( = 0.15406 nm). Differential Scanning Calorimetry (Model: Perkin Elmer Model DSC 7) were carried out at a scanning rate of 10 ◦C min−1 from room temperature to 400 ◦C and thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) of the films were performed (Model: TGA/DTA851e) under dynamic nitrogen atmosphere to investigate the thermal stability and glass transition behaviour of the samples.

.6. Antimicrobial property
The antimicrobial activity of films was evaluated against two ifferent pathogens; Gram negative bacteria Escherichia Coli (Eoli, MTCC 1687) and Gram positive bacteria Staphylococcus Aureus S-Aureus, MTCC 737) by Colony Forming Units (CFU/mL) method. he test organisms were grown in a Nutrient Agar Broth media t 35–37 ◦C for 24 h, a period of time sufficient for the growth of icroorganisms. 1 mL of culture was diluted with 99 mL of same roth solution to meet required bacterial population.10 mL of this iluted media was taken separately in five different dishes and he previously autoclaved rectangular pieces of films (20 × 20 mm) ere introduced separately into the dish. . Results and discussion
.1. FT-IR
Fig. 2a represents the FT-IR spectra of pure Chitosan. It exhibits broad band at 3322 cm−1 which can be indexed to the stretching ibrations of pendant groups like NH2 and OH present in the hitosan. The band at 2872 cm−1 corresponds to the asymmetric tretching vibrations of CH2 groups of the Chitosan chain. The tretching vibration of C O and C N groups in Chitosan is responible for the bands at 1564 and 1370 cm−1. The band obtained at 014 cm−1 arises due to the stretching vibrations of C O C linkges [20]. It is seen the spectra of pure Chitosan shows the low ntensity bands which can be attributed to the insufficient contact etween the film and the crystal surface [21].
The IR spectra of composite films are shown in Fig. 2b–e. The ncorporation of ZnO has greatly modified the IR spectra. It is evient from the spectra that the width of the bands corresponding o NH2 and OH groups is inversely related to the amount of ZnO articles in the chitosan matrix. This can be accounted by the reducion of hydrogen bonds between NH2 and OH groups with the ncorporation of ZnO particles onto the chitosan matrix [22]. As ompared to IR spectra of pure chitosan film, considerable shift n the position of bands towards lower and higher wave numer region is clearly visible in the IR spectra of composites ( NH2
OH from 3322 to 3355; CH2 from 2872 to 2866; C O from 564 to 1577; C O C from 1014 to1027 cm−1). This confirms tronger interaction between the functional groups and ZnO paricles. The incremental increase of intensities of IR bands at; 3349, 866, 1577, 1370, 1027 cm−1, is the indication of formation of coor-

dination bonds between various groups of Chitosan and Zn2+ ions of nano particles, hence it was concluded that ZnO particles would be located in between Chitosan chains connecting through the functional groups Fig. 3 [23].
3.2. XRD results
The XRD patterns of pure Chitosan and C-ZnC are shown in Fig. 4a & b–e respectively. The diffraction peaks observed in the composite films at various 2 values; 33, 36, 40.4, 54.3, 61 and 71.8◦ can be indexed to the position of the planes of ZnO particles (002), (100), (101), (110), (103) and (201) respectively. All these data were in well agreement with the data base of ZnO particles (JCPDS No.1436-51) [24–26]. The average particle size of ZnO crystallites was calculated using Sherrer equation, each composite films comprised of different sized nanoparticles (C-0.5/6.5; C-1/28.3; C-1.5/9.66 and C-2/7.73 nm). The XRD patterns of pure Chitosan exhibits peaks at lower 2 values (below 20◦), which can be correlated to the semi crystalline nature of Chitosan. The semi crystalline property of Chitosan arises from the compact arrangement of the polymer molecules in the presence of strong inter molecular hydrogen bonds [27]. The XRD patterns of C-ZnC show an interesting linear relationship between the intensities of major peaks and amount of ZnO nano particles. Moreover there was a notable shift in the positions of peaks. The variation of intensities and peak positions is due to the differences in size of ZnO nano particles and also due to the lattice strain developed in the composite because of the presence of nanoparticles [28]. Hence the XRD data underlines the dispersion of crystalline ZnO nano particles on the Chitosan matrix.

.4. Water adsorption studies of nanocomposite films
Water molecules in the surface of meat are highly vulnerale for microbial contamination. Hence packing materials which an quickly adsorb water molecules have great role in extending he shelf life of raw meat [29]. The adsorption capacity of all the lms in aqueous media was examined and the results are shown in ig. 6. The water adsorption ability of chitosan is due to the presnce of large numbers of hydrophilic groups in the polymer chain 30]. The intake of water molecules first increases passes through
maximum and then set down to a constant value indicating the quilibrium state of sorption. In contrast to pure Chitosan films, ll composite films exhibited higher adsorption capacity and are inearly proportional to the amount of ZnO particles. The incororation of ZnO nano particles onto the chitosan matrix increases he heterogeneity of the composite films. The formation of caviies as a result of introduction of ZnO particles in the films paves he way for more adsorption of water molecules. Another notable eature exhibited by all kinds of films was that the maximum limit f sorption was achieved as soon as the contact with water was stablished.
.5. Solubility of films
Solubility is the index of the stability of the packaging films in he presence of solvent molecules present on the food surface. If the ackaging film is soluble, it will deteriorate the quality of the food 31]. Since we aim to fabricate the packaging pouches for raw meat
hich posses’ large amount of water molecules on its surface, we
xamined the solubility of our packaging film in distilled water at oom temperature and the result is expressed as percentage of solbility. The trend of solubility of films with respect to the amount of
ZnO particles is given in Table 1. When the amount of ZnO increases the solubility decreases as there is a decrease in the availability of hydrophilic groups for interaction with solvent molecules, since ZnO particles cross links Chitosan chains connecting through their hydrophilic functional groups [32].
3.6. Thermal properties
The studies on thermal stability and glass transition temperature values of any polymer have vital importance in materializing the polymer into value added products. Here we have compared the thermal behavior of our novel composite film with existing popular synthetic packaging polymers. It was well evident from the DSC data that, all the composite films exhibits enhanced thermal stability and higher glass transition temperature over common synthetic polymers [33]. The DSC curves of naïve Chitosan and composite films exhibited two distinct peaks (Fig. 7). The first endothermic peak appeared at lower temperature region (323–383 K) corresponds to the dehydration of water molecules from the polymer lattice. Chitosan would adsorb the water molecules due to the presence of hydrophilic groups in the polymer, these water molecules being loosely bound to the polymer lattice are removed by heating in the temperature range 323–383 K. Generally the water molecules present in the biopolymer matrix can be classified into two types, namely “freezing and non freezing water”. The former type of water molecules could be removed easily by heating and would exhibit the bulk property of the water molecules [34]. The shifts in the peak values corresponding to the dehydration (C at 84.31,C-0.5 at 79.46, C-1 at 81.20, C-1.5 at 76.82 and C-2 at 77.50 ◦C) can be ascribed to the amount of water molecules in the matrix of different films [35]. The second major thermal behavior was registered as distinct exothermic peaks, corresponding to the onset of thermal degradation of polymers and the glass transition temperature (Tg) values. All the composite films exhibits significantly higher Tg values over the naïve Chitosan film (C: 272.73, C-0.5: 282.23, C-1: 279.98, C-1.5:

.7. Anti microbial property
The antimicrobial activity of bare Chitosan against S.aureus and .coli was investigated by colony counting method. The results of tudy are given in Table 2. Chitosan didn’t show any appreciable ntimicrobial activity towards both strain when compared to comosite films. The investigation also revealed that the antimicrobial ctivity is linearly related to the amount of nano ZnO particles in he composite films. Hence C-2 is the most efficient composite film gainst both E-coli and S-aureus and was taken the optimized film or packaging of raw meat. Literature survey hints to the fact that
the commendable antimicrobial activity of the composite relays on the presence of ZnO nano particles in the matrix. It is believed that the ZnO nano particles release reactive oxygen species (ROS). The ROS together with Zn2+ ions attack the negatively charged cell wall and will lead to leakage and ultimately in the death of the bacteria [38]. Moreover, the addition of ZnO, enhances the positive charge on the amino group of Chitosan. This results in easier interaction with anionic components on cell wall and composite films (Fig. 9). The decreased activity of all kinds C-ZNC towards S.aureus bacteria is due to the presence of thick layer of peptide glycans in its cell wall [39,40].
3.8. Packaging applications
The efficiency of the optimized C-2 film as a packaging material for raw meat was examined. Prior to the analysis, the C-2 films were kept in air tight poly ethylene bags for six months. The C-2 films were stitched into flexible pouch like bags using cotton yarn by an in-house weaving machine (Fig. 10). The shelf life efficiency of the composite bag was compared with synthetic plastic bag of low density polythene, which is popularly used to pack, store and transport meat and related items between producers and consumers in the market. The composite bags and plastic bags were sterilized by autoclaving at 121 ◦C for 15 min. The meat samples were collected from the local market and were washed well with distilled water to remove blood stains; equal amount of meat was placed in separate sets of bags, each set consisting of three duplicates of C-2 bag namely A1 SET and polythene bag namely B1 SET and incubated at 4 ◦C for 4 days. Following the 4th day of incubation, aerobic plate count was performed using the procedure described. This protocol was repeated for A2 SET and B2 SET and incubated for 5 days, followed for A3 SET and B3 SET and incubated for 6 days (Fig. 11).

. Conclusion
Four different Chitosan/nano ZnO composite films were syntheized by a simple one pot procedure. The presence of nano ZnO articles in the Chitosan matrix was proved well by FT-IR (ATR), RD and SEM techniques. Enhanced thermal stability of the comosite films was established by DSC technique. Water sorption bility of the films was calibrated and compared with pure Chiosan film. The solubility tests proved that all the composite films ere less soluble than pure Chitosan film and the solubility of the omposite films varied inversely with the amount of ZnO particles resent in the matrix of the composite. The usefulness of composte films to substitute current polythene bags to store meat and elated items were analyzed. The C-2 bag came out to be a star canidate by ensuring a total inhibition of the bacterial growth. The roposed film exhibits a great potential in the future for the packging pouches for meat via promising its impact on extending the helf-life of raw meat and controlling spoilage through complete nhibition of bacterial growth.

referenceMentions.context: Smart packaging refers to that form of intelligent packaging hich in any route extends the shelf life and improves the safety or ensory properties of food and allied products without compromisng its quality [1].
Apart from this, it must have portability, optimal water sorption capacity, high mechanical strength, physico-chemical stability, microbial safety, environmentally benign and cost effective [3].
Researchers have focused on chitosan as an alternative for petroleum derived polymer films [4].
Recently, the limited mechanical and antimicrobial property of chitosan films have changed the attention of researchers to modify naive chitosan films for better performance [5].

metadata.abstractText: As a breakthrough to open up the industrial use of novel environmentally benign packaging material, we propose the first report on portable chitosan-ZnO nano-composite pouches that will serve as elite entrants in smart packaging. A facile, one pot procedure was adopted for the preparation of the C-ZnC films. In order to tune the property of C-ZnC films, four different composite films were prepared by varying the concentration of ZnO. The prepared films were found to be much superior when compared to bare chitosan and other conventional films. Two bacterial strains that commonly contaminate in packed meat were selected as target microbes to elucidate the antimicrobial activity of the prepared C-ZnO film.
